page.title: 02FOUR MARKS : THEN
page.content: Then: In the early nineteen hundreds, water had to be drawn from a well. There was paraffin lighting and cooking was done on a cold range. People usually kept animals. With no television, people entertained themselves by playing football, tennis and playing in the woods. Fetes and garden parties were very small affairs. There were very few houses and no buses but very infrequent trains. Four Marks School was very small. There were only two teachers. The Headmistress was called the Governess. Some of the boys stayed at school until they were fourteen years old. Cars were very rare in those days. Most people got around by walking or cycling.
